Between 25 February and 10 March, the SMM recorded almost 15,700 ceasefire viola-tions (compared with over 23,000 in the previous two-week period). The Mission also observed 90 weapons in violation of the agreed withdrawal lines (62 in areas not con-trolled by the Government).

On 8 March, coinciding with International Women’s Day, a recommitment to the cease-fire made by the Trilateral Contact Group (TCG) came into effect. The SMM Chief Moni-tor and the Special Representative of the OSCE Chairperson-in-Office in Ukraine and in the TCG welcomed the recommitment (https://www.osce.org/special-monitoring-mission-to-ukraine/413648).

The daily number of ceasefire violations decreased following the recommitment, by around 60 per cent on the first day compared with the previous seven-day daily aver-age.

The Mission confirmed that five civilians were injured during the reporting period. This brings the total number of civilian casualties since the beginning of the year to 14: two killed and 12 injured.

Half of the civilian casualties confirmed this year, including the two fatalities, were a result of mines or unexploded ordnance. Despite the obligation to remove all previously-laid mines contained in the Minsk Memorandum and the TCG’s Decision on Mine Ac-tion, the Mission continued to observe the presence of mines, including newly-laid ones.

The position of weapons in and the firing from and into residential areas continues to endanger civilians. One man was injured in shelling in Donetskyi, where the SMM also noted the presence of armoured combat vehicles and mortars. In Zolote, the SMM ob-served fresh damage to three inhabited houses caused by shelling. Three infantry fighting vehicles were parked 10 metres from the houses. Two days later, SMM moni-tors and water company repair workers on the edge of the village were forced to leave the area following small-arms fire nearby.
